wkVeeeKNY4p2BLItc13bCA.text: i am really no expert on mexican food. i try again and again to like it, but mostly it just leaves me underwhelmed. i guess it's cos i like margaritas so much that i keep on trying, but maybe it is time for me to give up! (i will never give up on margaritas though...)accidentally came here on cinco de mayo (i have accidentally ended up eating mexican every cinco de mayo for the last four years, honestly don't know how i have done that!) with my boyfriend. i ordered the margarita of the month, which was a pineapple type affair. it was good, but small, and didn't taste particually potent. my next one was the classic margarita to gauge exactly how good they are - it was really sweet, not the best, and at £7.70 each, not cheap either.the food we got was good, but not mindblowing, and when the bill came, i was kinda disappointed that we had came and spent that money on food that wasn't amazing. we each ordered the pescado tacos, and i had the camarones (garlicky prawns and avocado), and my boyfriend some chorizo and cheese type taco. he's more into mexican food than i am, and even he was pretty underwhelmed.even though there seemed to be a lot of wait staff for a pretty small room, they were a tad inefficient. i had to ask twice for tap water, and they took forever clearing my first margarita glass, and then the plates from the table. i didn't think the atmosphere was amazing either.i was going to give this place 3 stars, but then reading back on my review it seems that there really isn't that much i actually enjoyed about it...so personally i wouldn't go again, but then mexican isn't really my thing. it may be yours and this place might work out better for you!

P9CVsFovi0ihn8lbt75yHg.text: It's about as good as you're going to get around here in London.  But why does a Taqueria have to be bright and sunny, a sit down place and (relatively) expensive.  Tacos are supposed to be cheap and with either Yucateco or Cholula sauce.  Oh, how I miss the Americas...But it'll do. :)

UpxGG6O7qjJ3kvoNB1Cdhg.text: Do they potentially make the best Margarita's in London? Perhaps. Seriously they were exquisite. Was the food tasty? Oh indeed it was. I even got to indulge in a fish taco with my very excited friend Lizzie. I have been told on good faith by my knowledgeable America bud Laura, that this is the most authentic Mexican food we have tried so far in London.The prices seemed reasonable, the service sketchy, and the atmosphere pretty non-existent, but the food was highly enjoyable if not quite making the mark of excellence.Oh yeah... If you are a tequila fan, you definitely need to go. They have a fabulous selection Jalisco goodness.

S5NzXg2IPSBK59VLC5m8yA.text: I'd say this is as good as it gets in London. The fresh made corn tortillas are great, tacos -- yummy, frijoles refritos -- delicious. Everything I've tasted here has been good, probably because the kitchen seems to be staffed with Mexican cooks. Strangely, though, most of the wait staff seem to be from Spain.The only "corn tortillas" usually available in grocery stores in London are gummy wheat flour-corn meal melanges so I was very excited to find out that I could buy some of Taqueria's genuine corn tortillas to take home for all my enchilada-making needs. Speaking of enchiladas, Taqueria also sells big bags of New Mexico chilies if you are inclined to make your own enchilada sauce.

x6-1U1T7QJgthxKPslZw5g.text: This is the best Mexican food I've had in London.  A lot less food-chainy than Wahaca & the margaritas are great.  The maracuya (passion fruit) margarita is so tasty it's dangerous.  I love the tacos - full of complex flavors and the habanero hot sauce is fantastic.  Service is friendly & the people watching on a Sat afternoon is always interesting.

UrL23Q4-9SGcQOSDH_Mjow.text: I think that I personally hold the title for most margaritas consumed at the Taqueria.  I have seriously injured my brain sucking down those tiny, salt lipped buggers on more than one occasion.   Problem is that at £8 a pop you really should get more than a little old school champagne glass for your 'rita.  However, they are still pretty delish.There is a huge selection of tacos served up with fresh corn tortillas.  I particularly like the tingas and the vampiro.  Yum!  Another fav of mine are the huevos rancheros.  Great food.  Beware of dishes that are incredibly spicy.  If you are a wimp, be sure to ask your server if your tastebuds can stand it.Only downside to the Taqueria is if you happen to visit on the weekend during the day.  It seems that many a Notting Hill family like to drag their toddlers to brunch and allow them to scream their heads off whilst banging their utensils on the tables.  Mum and Dad usually ignore these obnoxiously loud displays which grates my nerves and makes me want to throw a taco at said family.

lKyfxas1CaI3k2PGq8q0Cw.text: Definitely our favourite mexican place around these parts of town. Love their tacos and mexican beers. Not that anything else isn't good but these just always get me going there :)Also, really friendly staff. They even encouraged me to try out some of my elementary spanish!The only bad part for me in there are the bad acoustics. The place can get really noisy at peak times. Really noisy. Without that one big pain, I'd give it 5 stars.

0VBH94kkOe1UCu_W4pL3rA.text: There are two possibilities: 1) my expectations for Mexican food in London are so low that any place that is halfway good will make me happy, or 2) Taqueria has genuine potential. I got chicken enchiladas with green tomatillo sauce and a side of refried black beans. The chicken inside my enchiladas was not as flavorful as I would have liked, and the cheese on top -- which their menu promised as "queso fresco" -- was totally fine, but definitely not queso fresco. The beans were okay, but both the beans and enchiladas were screaming for a lot of salt.The tomatillo sauce, however, was wonderful -- very similar to the stuff I grew up on in Arizona and California. The staff was very friendly and welcoming. At one point, I was trying to ask if the beans were cooked in lard and I could see that the waitress didn't understand me, so I asked if she spoke Spanish. She did, we switched over to Spanish, talked about the beans (no lard!), and she continued to speak to me in Spanish for the rest of the meal. It made me feel very comfortable and at home :-) I would definitely give Taqueria a second shot, especially because good Mexican food in London is so woefully unavailable. There was enough promise in that tomatillo sauce to make me think there might be some other little gems on that menu!

rAF59w47fx7jpfECCMiu4A.text: Being Mexican this place caught my eye, starting with the tortilla making machine, I had to try and see if I could finally have a decent Mexican meal, one that is not confused with Spanish food, or Tex-Mex, or another of the aberrations I've encountered. I can prove that the place is legit, corn tortillas tasted like the ones at home; the only thing is the portions are too small, and if you know how much a taco really cost in Mexico like me, you'd think you are eating tacos filled with caviar. Try to go for breakfast and please enjoy huevos Rancheros, they are fantastic.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

cRFFK9V31Sa4baPOi837vw.text: Good but not great. I guess I am too spoilt by Mexican food across the Atlantic

aliYS3uCiB-WAuW4HDCRmQ.text: I love it here.I used to live just around the corner and my flatmates and I used to come at least once every week. It serves delicious cheap, quick and fresh food and the service is excellent. Not only are the waiters friendly and helpful, they are also very good looking.Generally, we get 2/3 small dishes each- usually I get the pork and pineapple tacos, the chorizo sopes and the chicken tinga and we share a bowl of rice plantain. It is great to go on any of the Mexican holidays- we went a few years ago on Independence Day and they did an excellent set menu, with music.The cocktails here are delicious.

-bjW4Y3FQQjrrJx7PVjqcw.text: When you eat at Taquiera, they serve you a dish of spicy sunflower seeds to nosh on before you get your food. Most of Taqueria's dishes are small. It's sort of a Mexican Tapas bar, complete with Spanish music and ambiance. The Cerviche is wonderful and so is the pork taco with a citrus kick. If you get one of the small plates, it's a snack. Two of the smaller plates, a meal. One big plate 3/4 of a meal. This place is a great deal. They give you the sunflower seeds with spice no matter what you order and do a guacamole with a consistency to die for,

VSJ6KQ4X1rWBuQeBgO9TpA.text: was taken last night for my birthday; I wont repeat everythign that has been said in other reviews about how the food is good and wouldnt it be nice if it were cheap like we have in {la,nyc,san diego, guadalajara, etc.} but I also really liked the atmosphere and the service:- it was crowded, warm, friendly, and buzzy- It was my birthday and without being asked, the staff overheard this  and all gathered round to sing "las mananitas" and were generally  nice (possibly because Im a native spanish speaker but all  the other tables looked pretty happy too)- Will definitely be returning, when Im in notting hill, which is alas  rarely.When oh when can we have a real mexican place with tacos, platos fuertes, pozole, menudo, and so on for a reasonble price in london? Almost all of the raw material can be sourced in the EU so Im not buying that its the cost of import.

ensuWdJmJ7v18Y5rEp7cBA.text: This restaurant is not only a good place to eat, it's also a retail operation selling Mexican ingredients home cooks have trouble finding in local supermarkets. They serve a soup with chicken, chickpeas, avocado, and rice that's out of this world. You actually can create a delicious and filling meal by combining some of the sides like garlic spinach, rice with peas, carrots, and fried plantains, and pinto beans with tomatoes, onions, and green chiles. Be sure to try the vanilla pudding with hibiscus syrup for dessert. Monday through Thursday only, they accept reservations for parties of six or more.

WyxRiieTHaKwZ-y71vuJ3Q.text: The food is very very good  the finest Fish Taco I've ever had  but portions are too small for the price. Also, the service is lousy. And unless you've booked, you face having to wait fifteen minutes or more for a table.

jPT6xHlj7OD7xdDccCJjpA.text: So maybe I have been in London too long because I know that I am probably being more forgiving than I normally would about a Mexican food place, but I thought this place was REALLY good for London. Maybe I don't remember what "real" Mexican food is like, but the second I walked in the front door the smells let me know that I was in the right place.This is not your "dirty mexican" sold at a drive through joint at 2 am like I know all of us Californians are craving, but it was more like one of those lil taco restaurants that you have to sit down in and eat like a human being, not a drunk/hungover mess of amazingness. This includes small portions, the plates usually consist of 2 or 3 tacos, so we had to get a few sides. which included refried and "the other kind" of beans that AREN'T refried. But for me, one of the biggest differences was the chips! I don't mean fries you brits! i mean tortilla chips! they weren't those fake, grainy corn chips that you can get at sainsburys for 25 p for a bag. these were those smooth oily chips made from something that once resembled a tortilla. and they had REAL mexican ingredients! things on the Menu that reminded me of a distant time when i used to eat mexican every day. things that have become forgotten from my dialect because I stopped saying them. like Jamaica, or totopos (not potatoes).I got camarones al ajillo, but someone at the table next to me ordered a fish taco, and i wanted to eat theirs too... so we got plantains and an extra avocado and it was HEAVENLY.I heard that they make their own tortillas at the restaurant and it really makes a difference.I will definitely be going back. Preferably on a thursday, b/c they have margarita specials for £2 off the reg price. and next time I am getting the Fish taco and the Tortilla soup. don't even TRY to talk me out of it. ok? WHO'S COMIN' WITH ME?!

29ZhovndZ30lnT3x28ttUw.text: It is HARD to find good Mexican food in London, and this place offers the the best fix for Americans needing a taste of home.  Authentic flavors, fresh ingredients, lovingly prepared and served by a very nice family (I disagree with another reviewer that they are not friendly).  The guacamole is great.  The carnitas are perfectly spiced.  The michelada (lime juice and beer) is really refreshing change from the typical heavy pint on a hot summer day.  And Notting Hill is fun and this restaurant has great bus access.

Gz15p39bmj6Bg9UBwPirxg.text: I grew up not too far away from Mexico and have a big section of my heart dedicated to it's food, so living in London can leave you a bit heart broken.  We randomly went to this place and I was so happy that we stumbled upon it.  The interior was cute and they had some Mexican wrestling playing on a t.v.  They served Pacifico, fish tacos and chilli rellanos, all of which I have never seen in England.  I was disappointed by the chicken tortilla soup (tasted more like tomato soup), but everything else was really good.  I had the fish taco and it reminded me of home.  The ceviche was really good too.  The manager was really friendly and kept in contact with us as tables became ready.  I highly recommend this to anyone who misses real Mexican food.

VmuaghxaWGlC9wrMaekIcA.text: I really enjoyed the food, and it sits high on my list of Mexican places, but really it is far too expensive for the portions. And the drinks are ridiculously expensive as well. If you are looking for a filling meal of mexican typish food for a good price, I would recommend to go elsewhere. (Wahaca, Mestizo, La Perla, etc).

nxxU14KrE173p3vGmRgwPQ.text: This is the closest you can get to authentic Mexican dishes in London.  While a number of similar places are popping up, the spices and flavors used at Taqueria are divine.  And the place is cheap -- sorry to say, but by London standards this place is a bargain.  My only complaint is the weird fish & chips type tacos that they serve. It may be positioned as a fish tacos but really it is fish & chips in a tortilla. I know we're in the UK but I'm not sure all tastes need to be taken into account.

CPjibbhbnYM2SqwB3f8_xA.text: Loved the food, went with a couple of friends & ordered a selection of tacos to share. The portions are small, so it can work out as expensive if you're hungry. My favourite thing about this place: the most delicious passion fruit margaritas, perfectly mixed! Try them, yummy! Will be back in the new year for more :)

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

S_ElNKZq18RbTf_7i5K-pA.text: This was my first Mexican on the other side of the pond experience, and it was A-OK.  I would definitely come back and try some other things on the menu.I had the fish tacos, which were good, but I wanted a little bit more flavor.  Refried and frijoles were well seasoned and what you would expect.  Horchata was great - a little more watery than what I'm used to, but that was a good thing in this case.  On the plus side, they use sustainable fish!As the restaurant filled up towards the end of our lunch, I noticed that the non-taco dishes looked much more exciting.  Next time I will opt for the flautas or maybe enchiladas.Service was friendly, though somehow didn't get the job done quite right. Though there were a lot of people on staff - I can remember at least five in the front of the house - the food all arrived at different times, which took away from some of its goodness actually - think room-temperature refried beans.Also not what I would call a value place.  The portions were quite small, and my lunch date actually walked away hungry. Full disclosure - I'm from CA, where Mexican cuisine is so plentiful and developed that you can get the best burrito you ever tasted for about 3 pounds.

9Q97FqB36yNuVpDdh54hsQ.text: I've really been missing good Southern California Mexican food!  I found some the other day at another restaurant here in Notting Hill that ROCKED, but of course I'm willing to try another place that had great reviews.....So from the reviews I was hoping that this place would be more like home, (San Diego, CA), and that I would finally get some carne asada like the Mexican restaurants in California make.The atmosphere was so so, nothing special.  The staff is friendly enough and go all out to make sure they seat you right away and check on you often to make sure you're doing OK.  I like that in a restaurant!  One thing that London seems to NOT have a lot of, is good customer service, but this place has it!I'm sorry to say that the food wasn't anything special, but was OK.  I had the Carne Asada Taco's and the meat didn't have any spices and hardly any flavor, and the sauces that they brought out to put on the taco's weren't that good either.  What the waitress said was hot sauce, was very mild.  Normally when you order carne asada tacos you get rice or beans along with it, but this place gave me just 2 tacos on a very small plate.  That's it!  I thought the price was ridiculous for just 2 small tacos.  My husband had the Huevos Rancheros.  He got a lot of food and he thought it was pretty good.  Not great, but pretty good.  I tried it and it was better than my tacos.....I would recommend this place if you were in the area.  I will probably go back and try something else on their menu just to be fair, plus I need to try their margaritas still.But only one thumb up for me!

rxR7LYBtcRvAUiqqe6bi-g.text: This is the best Mexican we've had so far in London, although we've only been for a short while.  Make sure to make a reservation if on the weekend, it's a small place and it gets quite busy.  The bartenders are terrific - very skilled and very nice if you have to chat with them while waiting for a table.  The margaritas are amazing - all fresh ingredients, super tasty.  As for the menu, I didn't mind the small-plate style, but my husband wished the portions were larger.  Some of the tacos were dead on, and some were lacking.  The churros for dessert were fabulous.  Overall, a great restaurant in Notting Hill.

59gxS5RMO2uA5ybci7MocA.text: Lets starts with my 3 most important questions when it comes to Mexican:Q) Hows their guacamole?  A) deliciousQ) And the margaritas?  A) excellent (esp the watermelon one!)Q) What about the quesdillas?  A) really goodI've been looking forward to trying Taqueria for some time now after hearing mixed but mainly positive reviews.  It's as close to authentic tex-mex that I've ever had on this side of the pond!  I'll absolutely be heading back to Taqueria!

vYPOpRIWJx-c0bxI1JHFow.text: youtube.com/watch?v=S95D…Fish Tacos, you'll have to wait while I catch my breath after all the excitement!Fish Tacos... seriously, 'effin fish in a taco! When I first saw this film after peeing in my pants while giggling to "I seend it, I seend it!" the Fish Tacos quote had me on the floor holding my sides. What was this crazy person talking about putting fish in a taco. Anyway, when I was informed that this was actually a proper traditional Mexican thing I just had to hunt it out and try it.Laura N thank you for taking me here and thank you for pointing this out on the menu, with it being in Spanish i would have passed over this without a second glance. And what was so great about this is that when it arrived I really like it. Like a fish finger wrap only better because they called it a Fish Taco.Now this place could be a top eating spot for me, the only problem was that it was a week night and pretty early and the place was so empty that it lacked a little atmosphere. Lovely food though, and awesome cocktails. I don't know if I mentioned it but the Fish Tacos are pretty friggin' awesome to.Ha ha ha, Fish Tacos!

iCjadcyFHOwGai4mQQZHCw.text: Arggggg.... you're so close! But yet so far...The menu could have been photocopied from a seedy dive on La Cienega, and the margarita was nearly perfection. (Just the fact that they don't use some overly sugared marg-mix is a step up from the closest competition.) These were both very very very good signs! However the tacos were a bit off and exorbitantly expensive. The ingredients were there -- corn tortillas, fresh chilies, dried herbs, black beans -- but the sour cream and salsa were disappointing at best, and stand-ins for mayo and ketchup at worst. The atmosphere was far too sterile and service (other than the fantastic manager who originally sat us) was non-existent.  However I will give some bonus points for hearing Spanish being spoken by all the servers as well as the kitchen staff, which again, is a huge step above the closest competition. Seriously, at least one star was given from hearing the correct pronunciation of "Taaah-co" vs. "TacK-o." So the search continues...

DGlNZQVDbj6sBR-bTBeCwA.text: I'm just gonna put it out there - the only reason I went to Taqueria in the first place is because Gwyneth told me to. goop.com/newsletter/67/enPhew. With that out of the way, let's get to the real review.I don't have Gwynnie's kind of dividends, so no... I wouldn't necessarily return to Taqueria if I was after some delicious tacos. I couldn't justify the cost.It is a beautiful restaurant though and the window seats are perfect for people watching. All those beautiful Westbourne Grove folks in their designer clothes. I LOVE IT THERE.Suzanne H and I took full advantage of their margarita madness - it was a very nice take on the beverage, served in a martini glass with a salted rim. Classy.Something else that caught my eye was the giant selection of special spices and chilis to buy. They even have bags of handmade tortillas for sale. That's nice - you can't find this stuff very easily in London.Fried plantains = best part of the meal.

krpZ_ag-KCYWSXFcEmdCgA.text: Good food but portions are small and pricy! Nice margaritas tho.

8zIM5nhY3HRUmqMS96YlZA.text: Food is delicious and it's a great place for small groups.  The restaurant itself is small and gets quite loud at night on the weekends.  I wish they didn't take the scallops off the menu though. Those were DIVINE!!

swd4ire9yZitH7NpumLEsA.text: Like all the reviews previously this place is good but could definately be better. The fish ceviche is the best thing they do but it does have a cold feel service can be awkward and prices add up quickly.When in Notting Hill and you crave a Taco this is a good place to choose as long as you leave your calculator at home and have no preconceptions. Take it for what it is "the first Mexican in an expensive British neighbourhood"

GfkY_m1gfwfvxvw44vevAA.text: It's not the first time I come to this place and I don't think I enjoyed it as much as the last. Service was really slow with a very poor handover of the tables after my initial waitress left the place rushing home.. And from there on it was a long wait for my beer standing just 2mts away from the bar and with only 3 tables in the restaurant. The food on the other side, is really good, it's one of the only places where I can find real mexican flavours, my starter was a black been sope it was good but the cheese wasn't melted on top like is supposed to, then a very well done ceviche tostada, garlic scallope tacos (they were good but could not taste the garlic in them) and finally an exotic chilorio duck tacos with honey, mexican with a twist and the best example of the exquisite and modern take on mexican food from taqueria. Overall it was pleasant but I expected more from the service.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

nZ_NNgg2-bZStAA3qdMAlQ.text: fantastic tacos, meh margaritas.  better than terrible service...my especial margarita had hair in it and they brought the bill for another table.  i'm a tex mex girl (the real kind, not like the place on nh gate/palace gardens) so a mean margarita plus salad = heaven.  after dinner at taqueria, we walked to crazy homies for margaritas.

sUcFG-osWp-_ZTVfNmkZbA.text: I was VERY disappointed with this place.The interior is kinda cold (it would be better to go here for lunch, not dinner) and the staff are not friendly.At first the prices seem reasonable, but the portion sizes are small, which explains this!The ceviche is pretty tasty, although there is not much fish on it!I was not impressed by the pork and pineapple tacos.Everything was very 'Meh' and I left here feeling hungry - so decided to have a Mexican bonanza night and went directly to Crazy Homies to get more food!Trying to find good, reasonably priced Mexican food in London is starting to annoy me!!!!

pqRDXa3QwofNmd2yUWEeHg.text: We really enjoyed Taqueria, AMAZING margarita's with our favourites being the classic and the naranja with chilli powder around the rim. The carne asada tacos were the best of the evening, although they were small for £5, and the carnitas were at the bottom of the list as they really didn't have much flavour. This place is a bit pricey but well worth the food and DEFINITELY for the margarita's, excelente! I'll be going back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

EmQ3NBSHmIp_30v4VSNH7w.text: Excellent food.   I will be back.   Trying different items on the menu and so far so good!  I will be back the next time I'm in London

C4N7vP74blvQ5C9qAEU7VQ.text: Friends took me here due to my known love for mexican food. I must say that Taqueria has pretty good food, but I was still a bit disappointed. I was expected to be flown away and even though my Fajitas were good and so plentiful that I should have shared the dish, they were also very, very greasy and had too many onions. Nonetheless, I would go back here and give it another shot, since the general food was good and the staff was friendly.

WrUTghQdGmyCcLNi8pUg8w.text: This is the closest thing you will find in London to authentic Mexican food...finally.  However it comes at a price.  In LA you can buy the same taco for .60p but here its a whopping 5-6 quid for two.  On top of this they can't even justify the pricing with a nice atmosphere, it looks like what it is supoosed to be a hole-in-the-wall taqueria with cheap tables and chairs and a very cafeteria feel.  You are paying for importing a cuisine to expats in Notting Hill.  With that said, the food is very good, but the menu is quite standard. Besides trying the tacos (fish were my favorite, its the sauce), you must have an elote. Corn smothered in mayo, rolled in crumbled white cheese and sprinkled with chili powder.  Hmm...sounds off?  Not a chance, its delicious.  Every once and a while they would have a special that was interesting like Mole, which is worth a try.  The Margarita happy hour specials are reasonable and the staff is satisfactory. Definately worth it if you have every had real Mexican food and realise that eating at Chiquitos is not okay.

KM9lw1fZkZ6G3Ufy_HB0RQ.text: Instead of giving this place three stars, I'd rather give it a frowning face like this :( simply because this is how I felt after coming here. The service wasn't bad, but the food was just not what I heard it was and definitely didn't meet even a minuscule degree of quality Mexican food. I've had better carne asada tacos made by some guy on a hibachi in the trunk of his car in TJ (Tiajuana). Again, the food wasn't bad, it was just disappointing. And by disappointing, I mean disappointing in the way when your parents have that talk with you and say they aren't mad you stole the car and crashed it, they are just disappointed in you; which is WAY worse. Plus side of this smallish little restaurant in the Notting Hill Gate area is their selection of Mexican beers and tequila. They had some good choices, not plentiful, but good. I savored Pacifico and enjoyed several. One thing you don't really see in many Mexican places in Mexico or the States is they offer you your beer "chilada" style, which is served in a glass with lime juice (not a lime), salt on the rim and ice. Okay, I get it. I like Margaritas too, but I don't want the equivalent of a beer margarita. I want my lovely Pacifico sans glass with a slice of lime in it. Done. Simple, easy, clean, tasty. Also, this place does take reservations, just not on the weekends. Get there before 8:30pm or it begins to queue up.

z3iOD2iXUDQmvP4L9tOTKA.text: Nice margaritas and good chips and salsa.  The food is fine if you find yourself craving Mexican in the UK but don't expect anything amazing.  Very good homemade tortillas.My enchiladas were reasonably well spiced, however, you just don't get the real depth of flavor that you are used to elsewhere.Oh, and this is Notting Hill, not LA, so be prepared to pay.  Lunch for 3 plus a cocktail each set is back around £65.

_SofFpYk_IMWGE2Bzhm_Xw.text: Mexican food is what I've missed most from the US and in the year and a half that I've been living in London I didn't really find the 'perfect' place BUT Taqueria comes very, very close. I can't pin point exactly why they miss the mark but perhaps it's that entrees in the US are served with a side of rice and beans. Perhaps it's the salsa, perhaps the tortillas. All of which were excellent at Taqueria, but not the same. I guess some things just can't be replicated. New Yorkers will say the same thing about bagels (its the water). They have a little business selling their own chips and jarred salsas with a lovely display on one wall. Anyway, lovely little place and ironically, after dinner, a walk down the street revealed two more Mexican restaurants in the neighborhood. But my friend and host assured me that Taqueria is the place to go.

Mebaa_7P32aLu4PKLEoi9g.text: I think it speaks to the popularity and authenticity of the restaurant when you come for dinner on a Monday night and the place is packed to the brim and you hear Spanish all around you.  As an LA boy, I was feeling a bit homesick and had read the reviews of this place so I decided to check it out and decide if the hype was real.  If I stepped outside after dinner and was hit by a bus, I would have been okay with Taqueria having been my last meal on earth.  The meal was as follows:Free spicy peanuts plus a genuinely ice-cold Pacifico (booo London corner shops and your lack of closed refrigeration); this was an excellent start to the mealTacos al pastor: they came in thicker slices with pineapple, not as good as the diced version in LA but added a little habanero sauce and it was magic.  The tang of the pineapple and the spice of the sauce plus the slightly chewy but buttery texture of the pastor was a fiesta in my mouthTacos chorizo mexicano: I was expecting the breakfast burrito type chorizo but this was fresh and moist ground sausage, with a sprinkle of crisp onions and cilantro - way better than I expected and had a simple taste unladen with spicesTacos de pescado: gotta have a classic right?  This was truly one of the best fish tacos I've had, the batter was light and crisp, the sauce was slightly smoky, and the guacmole had chunks of fresh avocado in itHuarache w/ cactus, onions, salsa and queso fresco: hadn't had huaraches before and I was expected more of a thicker tostada.  Instead, it was a thinner fried version of a tortilla, but man the way the onions were cooked were amazing - caramalised but still slippery and soft without a overly burned tastePlatanos with caramel sauce and vanilla ice cream:  the plantains were also lightly fried, caramalised but not super heavy or burnt.  The chopped peanuts bookended the start of the meal with a familiar taste and texture but part of an altogether different dishEach dish hit the spot, and I was actually sad when the meal was over.  Partially because it was so good but also because the restaurant was somewhat expensive.  I don't doubt that all quality ingredients go in to the food, and that it's made to order, but to pay c.6 pounds for three small tacos is a lot to ask for.Despite the price, I still give this 5 stars for the food, atmosphere and decent service.  Real recognise real.

sBYmfQOS9st__OaczA6Jnw.text: Good food but soooo expensive for what you get - but guess in line with all other things in the area:-) I like their dopes and some if the tostada ( I like shrimp one) food is just good so don't expect to have something amazing... But you would definitely enjoy the mouthful - I would never travel to eat here but good option if you are in the area.

00AZbDiigoS98EVMOSShSA.text: This place is full of itself. The tacos are okay, the service is barely okay, the prices suck. I know this is the second review in a row that I have complained about prices. I'm not a cheap skate. I just hate people making pseudo authentic food and thinking that they can rip you off. Perhaps it's a great place if your are a yuppie trying to impress a date by taking her to Notting Hill and ordering "real Mexican" food. If this is what Mexican food is going to be in my adopted home town, just open up some Del Tacos or Taco Bells and be done with it. On the way home, I stopped for kebabs.

JxCssV8whuKGDXINIfZJbw.text: I was stunned at how good my meal was here.  I am an absolute stickler for Mexican food (a native Texan fanatical about Mexican food).  I've been staying a few blocks from Taqueria for the past few weeks but had been hesitant to go because I didn't want to be disappointed.  While I would probably give this place 4 stars as a very good Mexican restaurant in the U.S., for London and based on vastly exceeding expectations, I think this place merits the highest rating.  The meal that two of us just had there was outstanding.  We ordered a few items, each were excellent - I had no complaints: (1) Tortilla Soup and a different Chicken Soup that came with avocado, onion, chickpeas, rice.  (2) Enchiladas Suizas de Poblano: cheesy enchiladas with a filling composed of potato and embedded poblanos, topped with some fresh slivers of poblano.  (3) Cochinita Pibil: 3 pork tacos topped with pickled red onion.  (4) Black beans. (5) Chips with a two salsas: a green tomatillo and a brown chile salsa. Everything was truly excellent.  Great service.  With a beer and coke, the bill was a little over £30.

1kK68Fo_uYBfdeQaY7ZUvQ.text: Horrible service, and crap food should be a winning combination, but somehow it doesn't work here.We left after our starter so this isn't a comprehensive review, but seeing as we literally couldn't continue eating there I'd say you should take my advice and avoid this sorry excuse for a mexican restaurant.  We got some sort of tortilla chips served with beans and guacamole and a tiny bit of salsa.  The chips themselves were partially stale, and were just awful (granted, London doesn't have great tortilla chips anywhere but at least source them from the same place as Chilango or Chipotle).  The beans were strangely glowing black and were covered in some Mexican cheese which was somehow grated to look like white mouse droppings.  Oh, and the cheese was rotten and both my wife and I were ill a few hours later.SHORT VERSION: WE GOT SICK FROM THE FOOD AND THE WAITRESSES ARE D-BAGS.

HL1GE1r4WSs-Nk0A2ZTNoQ.text: This is a rating for a London Mexican food. :-)There are a number of Mexican places that have popped up in London to try to offer good Mexican food, and this place does well. It is somehow missing some sort of spiciness, roughness or earthiness that I tend to like in a taco, but you are in Notting Hill.The tacos Al Pastor were okay, but the sauce is not quite correct from what I'm used to. The chicken Tinga tacos were not a flavor I was familiar with, though they seemed a bit bland.The two standouts were the baked cheese appetizer and the Puntas Albañil, which was sort of like a fajita in a taco. With the hot sauce, these were great.This is pretty close to where I live, so there's a good chance I'll be back the next time the taco craving hits.Gluten-free notes: Their corn tortillas are just corn. They're happy to tell you what does or doesn't have wheat, and mark a few wheaty items on the menu. Beware of one beer-batter-fried taco filling.

6HJcDPGEnhn1o9aTtZt8wg.text: This place was very good. As an American living 40 min from the Mexican border, I didn't think we would find decent Mexican food in the UK. The shredded pork tacos were some of the best I've had. We ordered lots to taste everything. Definitely go here!

ZpEsWzIvZpn5io5B2yGmAA.text: You've got to grade Mexican food in London on a curve, so based on that this place gets an A+.  My culinary opinion, as a Californian that lived in London from 2004 to 2008, this place was a oasis for a lot of crappy Mex-like places.The best mushroom quesadillas I've ever had in my life; heavenly potato flautas, fresh aguacate and zesty elote.  The margaritas are damn good too.  And absolutely don't pass by their weekend brunch!  They have dynamite huevoes rancheros!

qsTfxjzUToQC-BMAGt0VRA.text: Best tortilla soup I've had in London, New York or San Fran.  I'm not a fan of their chicken soup, though.I prefer the tacos here to the ones I've had in the US purely because they are not ENORMOUS. The ratio of tasty filling to tortilla ratio is perfect. My favourites tacos are Vampiro and Huaraches (although I note that they've stopped using blue corn and are just using regular white or yellow corn for the slipper tortilla -- bring back the blue!!) but they're all very good.The margaritas are also not half bad!Service is variable (unsurprisingly correlated to to the presence of the manager) hence the four stars. I'd give it five for food, though.

vfq1q9G3SWmoLwwMCgHICQ.text: As a mexican myself, Im always a bit sceptical of any mexican food overseas. This was fine. Saturday evening was packed! as it seems to be quite popular in the Notting Hill area.They had a good selection of tequilas and special tequila of the month, Tequila Ambar, which was a great choice indeed!They have some good beer as well. Staff was very nice. Somehow it gets you wanting to come back.

4Tp4PnF-j_FvmK_KWLvYxg.text: I have been living in London for a year now and this is my favorite restaurant. We try to go at least once a month. Could the service be better? Sure, but not everything is perfect :)  The food is delicious and hits the spot every single time.  My favorites are the Vampiro, the Mexican Corn (with mayo and cheese), the Tostada de Ceviche and Warache. I always try to leave a little room for the churros with homemade cajeta - yu-ummmm.Margaritas and Micheladas are also good, and generally quite spicy so ask them to make it less so if your tolerance is human.If you are into cooking, the people from Taqueria also sell the Cool Chili Company products, so you can get authentic tacos, hot sauces, beans and mole.

kxTNxCCNPHi9Abba_gQUVg.text: The tacos were simply alright and the price to food ratio was way too high.  I had carne asada tacos.  The meal was a few strips of meat, no distinctive seasoning, served with some guacamole and salsa fresca.  The guacamole was acceptable, but didn't have much flavor other than lemon.  The salsa fresca was forgettable.  The portion didn't quite kill my appetite, but I wasn't really interested in spending a second £6 for another taco.I tried both the agua de jamaica and the horchata.  Both were fine.  The high point of the meal was dessert: fried plantains with ice cream and a Mexican caramel called cajeta.  It tasted pretty good.  I hadn't had cajeta before, but I'll look out for it in the future.

O8e0jEVzjlpOodL9GKGehA.text: GREAT VALUE! Not as good as Mexican food in San Diego or SF, but great for London!  Really good tacos (esp fish tacos), and really cheap.  Dinner for two for less than 20 pounds.  We'll be coming back for sure.

2u8YSaQXbbcDKRT31T613w.text: The food was incredible and very high quality. The service, however, was a completely different story. The waitress we had was incredibly under-trained in terms of restaurant etiquette. Immediately after receiving our food, she immediately asked "Is there something wrong with your food?" out of nowhere, leaving us all uncomfortable and speechless. The table was constantly being cleared without even being asked if we were finished with the remainder of the food or our drinks (clearing the glasses with a significant amount of alcohol left in the glass). After all of this, the waitress put the bill on the table without our request for any bill. This was ignored, as we continued to finish our drinks, only to have the waitress return with a card machine asking us how we wish to pay (AS IF WE WERE AT AN APPLEBEES IN MIDDLE AMERICA). Because of this, my experience was completely thrown off and constantly interrupted. Very disappointed in this waitresses' lack of table etiquette at an actually very potentially enjoyable restaurant. Disappointing.

NrchRwswPy6eGGswbKGsFA.text: As good as it gets for Mexican food in London.  Was craving fish tacos and they nailed it.  Pork and beef tacos were good as well.  Great flavor.  Three of us in total and we walked away 100% satisfied.  Good service. I will be back!

jmwD-b3LRVu9SS-pqmvpdw.text: I had my birthday dinner here tonight, and had to rush home immediately to give this place the 5 stars it deserves. I was hugely impressed that Taqueria is a member of the SRA (Sustainable Restaurant Association) and actively do their best to reduce energy consumption in the restaurant, and support sustainable fishing. Also, they only use free range eggs, chicken and pork. The carnitas were out of this world. The margaritas were strong (and pricey) and well made. The Camarones al mojo de ajo were fantastic. Definitely order a couple of dishes each off the menu, the portions weren't too big and it's worth it to be a little greedy.The service was sweet and helpful, but a little slow. We didn't get much attention after we'd finished our meal and were waiting for a dessert menu. Not bad at all, just not perfect. I will definitely be going back!

Cv_HjxuOfZdL3bDyAZDBFA.text: I like this one. At the Queensway end of Westbourne Grove this is a really chilled little Mexican restaurant. I have no idea really how authentic it all is but at least 10% of the menu is written in Spanish - a good sign - and they serve up really good Margaritas to go with them - a very good sign. It's got a little bit of an American diner style, with quite a bit of chrome and a big glass front window. When I was there the staff were mostly Mexican - another good sign - and the food was really nice. There were four of us so we ordered lots of different little dishes to share which seems to be the best option, frijoles, enchilidas, tacos obviously: they have a really good mix. I'm going back very soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

PnZRNEVecCwV9XEAln-VxA.text: Ay, caramba! Guacamole in London, how do I love the...Instant 5 stars!

E1hX0UyfjxBB3288s6-phw.text: Portions are SMALL for the price, but the place is friendly with a great atmosphere. The food is quality, really tasty but not overly salty. I hate Mexican food normally, not my cup of tea, yet I felt myself wanting to have more. Only I didn't want to shell out the money for another three small tacos. I remember the dessert, fried plantains, being really sweet but oh-so good. Here was also my first time trying horchata, and I have never tasted a better one since. It tasted classy at Taqueria, haha. If you're looking for a good Mexican place though, here is where it's at!

2bsSrNmzPyBI9PVp4xdbYg.text: I am sad that I haven't eaten a proper meal here yet; I just ducked in for a drink and apps to get out of a torrential downpour.   The apps were good (nachos, yum!) but what stand out was the daiquiri.  Hemingway would be proud!   It was top drawer stuff.

PcnO4IG-DIdLxYR1U35tFA.text: Really good Mexican style tacos!  So many to pick from it was quite difficult.  Everything we ordered was really really good.  The place is quite small so make sure to get there early to get a seat.One thing that is not authentic Mexican about this place is the price... wow, when the bill came it was amazing how much some tacos and drinks cost.

ZIGBSvKwMJXaL8pl7Ufsgg.text: I grew up on the border of Mexico, and ever since I left I've been on the quest to find restaurants that can satisfy my Mexican food cravings. Once I left the States I thought I'd never get good Mexican again until I went home to visit family, but then I stumbled upon Taqueria. The food is delicious! The tacos are tasty and the champiqueso is divine!  The service is definitely lacking, but not enough to keep me from coming back for more. The only downside is that they've been under renovations for months, thus robbing me of satisfying my craving. If you're ever in Notting Hill, do yourself a favor and avoid the hustle and bustle of Portobello Road. Head down to Taqueria and treat yourself to some delicious food.

XkoUPL92_LyeHYNktteuuA.text: As I've been wanting to try this for quite some time, I jumped on a brunch opportunity with a friend. Yet, the experience was mediocre.  It's cramped. Be prepared to literally be sitting on top of the table next to you. And, yes, conversations are heard all over.  It's cute, but it's just too tiny.As for the brunch menu, plenty of options including refried beans! Yet, I am allergic to avocado. I asked for them to not put any on my plate as I ordered a dish that could easily remove it.  Yet, the plate had it on it and was covering my meal. I'd still take Wahaca any day over this place.

svLtdTIhrrYhZDAaJRnZag.text: Terrible service. Rude general manager. Wow incredibly rude. I made the simple request of asking for one type of each taco which was done the last time I ate here. The general manager insisted that in 10 years that never happened. NO. IT NEVER HAPPENED HERE. TWO TACOS, ONE VARIETY. NO MIXING FOR YOU. Wow. Is it so complicated to have one type of each taco or to treat your customer with respect over a simple disagreement? Inflexible, rude service, overpriced, small portions. Please somebody open a proper Mexican place with good service.

Xxov7VUhVC3WJ2h1Q70Weg.text: EDIT:  Lowered the rating to 3.  I just can't justify the crazy prices with the toddler portions.  If an adult is trying to eat, provide more adequate portions!OK, disclaimer - I AM MEXICAN (via California) - I know what good Mexican food is.  And this place is probably the best in London.   But here is the thing.  Mexican food is for the people.  It's usually affordable and  amazingly tasty.  Well, Taqueria is at least amazingly tasty - BUT it is not affordable, hence only the 4 stars.   Should be 3.5.One thing I've had to get used to in London is that Mexican food is considered a gourmet cuisine.  On taste alone of the authentic food, absolutely...but not used to the hoity-toity prices for it.  Another thing is that in London, you have white guys making ethnic food.  Oh nooooo!   I'm used to whatever ethnic food you are eating, it is made by the actual people. At Taqueria, the food is very very good but the portions are RIDICULOUSLY SMALL!  For the price, you feel robbed.  But when you are dying for something authentic, you agree to the price gouging just for a sliver of authenticity.  How sad but when its time for your fix, you pay for it.  One thing though - our waittress was unattentive.  She was openly gossiping with another waittress and looked annoyed.  Take that sour puss attitude to the back where diners can't see your disdain.  I did notice all the workers speaking Spanish AND a Mexican cook!  Which shows me that there isn't some English bloke making my meal (like I saw at Lupita East...ugh)One cool thing though - they sell Mexican ingredients that are tasty!  They are the only place that sells corn tortillas.  If you are a true Mexican food expert, you know that flour tortillas are mainly for the gringos.  Finally was able to get more of an authentic taste.So, while I'm conflicted on price and portion size, I can't deny - this food is delicious.

wh1E0Mb2rGxOOqppsiEB2w.text: A very solid spot overall. The tacos here are tasty, filling and dynamic. The value is OK.Friendly service. The ambiance is nothing to shout about but perfectly comfortable.If you want a relatively low-key Mexican meal, this place should do the trick.

MzZXjGn4CnI8lJ-zCGpkzA.text: Service is super slow, but the churros are awesome - almost as good as ones I had in Spain. I thought the food was overpriced for the portion size, but I had a good soup and others enjoyed their tacos. Could have done better at Wahaca, though.

ybVGrddRbopPkie9OCVHkw.text: Great little spot for vegetarians to get stuck into to platefuls of Mexican! While there is a lot of great sharing dishes to choose from, the menu isn't overwhelming with choice like some other places. Which I always find to be a positive thing, I'd rather spend my time eating than pawing over page after page of options.   The tacos are incredible and spicy enough to add a good kick without making you sweat from the soles of your feet.   The hibiscus cocktails are incredible and brilliantly, Taqueria have it's only mini-market full of Cool Chile Company wares for you to take home to continue the fun of Mexican cooking at home.

SgHvrTXNwX0w7NPM3YyzOg.text: Although not the cheapest or best for Mexican food in London Taqueria hits the spot. We have eaten here twice and and both times were great experiences. They actually get quite busy on the weekend and we were told around 8pm on a Friday night the wait was about 45 minutes. The second time around we came for half off Monday taco night which made every bite taste that much better!Fortunately on both occasions the wait staff was very friendly and efficient. You just have accept the fact that this isn't going to be a delicious 2 dollar taco from California and just enjoy the meal for what it is.Quesadillas toasty corn tortillas folded around melted cheese with mushroom (v) £4.10, chicken or house made Mexican chorizo £5.10Al pastor char grilled marinated pork, pineapple, diced onion, coriander £5.60Gringa pastor (pork) and melted cheese sandwiched between 2 corn tortillas, onion, coriander £6.60Vampiro char grilled tortilla, melted cheese, char grilled skirt steak or mushrooms (v), Vampiro salsa £6.25Carnitas shredded slow cooked pork, green salsa, pickled jalapeño, diced onion, coriander £6.20Carne asada char grilled skirt steak, avocado mash, salsa Mexicana £6.60Pescado beer battered MSC Alaskan pollack, avocado mash, chipotle mayonnaise, Mexican salsa, shredded cabbage £6.65

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

B4CerKIwYD_KCI-ErImGPA.text: This place has both good and bad. The night we went (a group of about 10 of us), it was packed despite being a Thursday night.The food that we received was good, fresh, tasty but it was not cheap. Ok, it's Notting Hill, I can let that slide. My one big criticism is that the tortillas they serve the food in are just ok - certainly not the best and it wouldn't hurt if they were warm. The margaritas (I think £6?) were pretty good.What really let this place down was the service. We were 10 people - that's not a huge table and shouldn't be a problem for waitstaff (speaking as a 3 year veteran of the field). One of my friends waited 45 minutes for fish tacos only to be told that it wasn't ordered (which involved the waitstaff showing us that the only fish taco that had been ordered was delivered to the table because it was checked off their list...ok?). I had to ask 3 times (over 25 minutes) for some tap water to go along with my margaritas (margaritas served promptly, tap water not). This was particularly frustrating given that a lot of the waitstaff was standing around while we weren't getting what we needed.All in all, I wouldn't suggest this place for meeting up (I didn't feel that safe on the walk from Notting Hill Gate but that's my issue!) but I wouldn't refuse if others wanted to go here. I would be prepared to spend quite a bit and wait, though!

ERBEH6BBXK83XisWl9z9AQ.text: Taste and authenticity wise - I dare say - IT'S the BEST MEXICAN in London. The tacos and enchiladas served there are proper tacos and enchiladas / not just some tacos crisps served with mediocre salsa and basics) - proper small round tortillas with a variety of delicious warm fillings including pork, beef and many more in a combination with amazing flavours. This place serves authentic Mexican drinks and is usually quite busy.The decor is slightly overlooked but despite this.. It's the first place that comes to my mind when I think 'proper authentic, delicious Mexican food' :) outside Mexico.

bWAEFYByv7Do_OMnC3oWkQ.text: This has been my best Mexican restaurant experience yet, and it's been a long, long search. The food was absolutely delicious. I judge a Mexican restaurant on the quality of its rice and its guacamole and both were top notch. I also really enjoyed the fried plantains, which aren't served in many Mexican restaurants surprisingly enough.The portions here are not huge, but still I think it's reasonably priced. I had the carne asada tacos (which came as two 'large' tacos) and the arroz mexicana with plantains. I found this to be sufficient. I felt full but not stuffed. The margaritas are also nice and strong... can't go wrong with that!In my experience, the service was standard. We had no complaints. It was fairly easy to get the waitress's attention and they were nice and friendly. Also, at 7pm on a Saturday night, it was fairly easy to get a table for 3 (there were about 2 or 3 open at the time). Highly recommend!

0JiDFpRVxjjQhar5ToQLEA.text: This isn't simply one of those "it's good Mexican food...for London" type of places.  This is simply GREAT Mexican food.  And not Cali-Mex or Tex-Mex food - real authentic Mexican food.  The name would suggest that it's the type of place that serves quesadilla suizas, has a jukebox and Chivas de Guadalajara posters on the wall, but it's not.  This is really high-end Mexican comfort food.For a gringo, I'm a bit of a Mexican food snob.  I lived in San Francisco's predominantly-Mexican Mission District for 12 years, I studied Spanish in Guanajuato for a month, I got engaged in Guanajuato, I got married in Puerto Vallarta, and I've been to Mexico at least half a dozen other times.  I don't claim to be an expert on Mexican food, but I will say that this place is as good as any Mexican restaurant I've ever been to - including places in Mexico.Ok, maybe it's because I've been in London for 2 months and this is only the second time I've tried Mexican food here, the first being some bizarre Mexican-Italian place in Chelsea that we were satisfied with simply because it didn't completely suck.  Taqueria not only doesn't suck, it's the complete opposite of suck.  They have tacos al pastor garnished with pineapple - that wins huge points for authenticity right there. They make delicious and fresh chilitos rellenos.  They serve churros con cajeta.  That's right - they have cajeta.And what Mexican meal would be complete without drinks?  They have Pacifico, Negra Modelo, Bohemia, Dos Equis Lager AND Amber, plus they make both cheladas and micheladas.  Really good cheladas.  Their tequila selection is outstanding, and if that wasn't enough, Corralejo Reposado (the one in the tall blue bottle) is their default top-shelf tequila for fancy margaritas.  I freaking love Corralejo Reposado.I'm going to find it very difficult to not eat here at least once a week.  I can't wait to go back just to get a poloma and the pozole.Plus it's decently priced.  We splurged on 4 drinks, 3 orders of tacos, 2 appetizers and 2 desserts and the bill came to a relatively reasonable £54 with tip.  That's obviously not cheap, but I've spent at least that much on far lesser Mexican meals at restaurants of this caliber in San Francisco.  If you were more price-conscious then you could still easily get out of here for £15-20/person including a (really good) drink and tip.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. tacos alambres
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. tacos al pastor
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. churros con cajeta

TRqBJ0BPjO668nymP7rCNQ.text: For Mexican food in London, this place is pretty good, and closer to authentic Mexican then other places I have tried in the city. But my amigos, it needs a dash more chile, and much more tequila. I am not trying to be a taco snob here, but when Mexican is done right, it is AMAZING! You have not lived until you have had proper tacos al pastor. Spiced pork cooked on a rotisserie like a shwarma, with spicy seasonings. It is then cut in small slices right off the rotisserie as it cooks, and the meat put into tortillas with pineapple chunks, chopped onion and cilantro to taste. It is soft and crunchy at the same time and one of life's great culinary delights. So with this craving I went to Taqueria and yes, it wasn't what I expected. I think these were beef instead of pork and sauce was added to make it seem like the real thing, but it missed the mark. In saying that, for London Mexican, it was pretty darn good, and the place had a fun cantina feel. The other tacos I tried were tasty as were the quesadillas. I would definitely go back. Colorful and festive, a bright spot on a rainy day.

Rz8tdLS9VkNfscQkD8h4zw.text: The food was excellent but serving sizes were quite small. Service was quick and friendly.  I will come back. This is a good find.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

GZFIHUkii45JcfkQhFJeyg.text: Sometimes bad things happen to good people. Luckily, my group wasn't the good people whom bad things happened to when we went to Taqueria, but the group whose table we were given were pretty pissed by the whole thing and ended up leaving. The confusion in a reservation that left two large parties and only one large table could have gotten quite nasty -- after all, having some lady come up and accuse you of stealing her table, when you came in on time and were seated by the hostess, can generally leave one feeling as though they have a right to the table they are at. The restaurant did their best to diffuse the situation, though of course not everyone could be pleased. I will say that it was good luck for the restaurant that they didn't kick us out, as our party kept growing, spending, and little did they know that both Tequila Tuesday and a Yelper were at the table. That can go really poorly if you put those people out of the restaurant, especially when they were timely and indulgent patrons.There are other things though, that unfortunately weren't perfect. My friend is gluten free, and if you can believe it, they have no corn tortilla dishes. EVERYTHING has flour, except for the tortilla chips, which she was forced to have for dinner. That's just disappointing, especially since so many restaurants know how many people can't eat gluten, and so many Mexican restaurants are realizing the value of corn tortilla both in taste and customer satisfaction.Additionally, they were a bit overwhelmed by us, despite having planned on a big party. Dishes came out quite haphazardly and we spent a lot of time trying to figure out who ordered what and where, etc. In the end, the drinks were great, and the food tasty, and it all worked out, but it's still tough when it's not a strong performance for the serving staff. Nonetheless, as Tequila Tuesdays go, it's definitely not the worst I've had. A solid middle score restaurant, I'd say.

VFs6Nz2ahWVOrBO367ut0Q.text: A reasonable facsimile of Mexican food.Marred by a pretentious Euro/UK attitude biased toward small portions.You will not find a Burrito as thick as a mans arm here. Not cheap either.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Margarita Mandarina
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

dndc64UMjSYcO5CG0aNaTA.text: Nice atmosphere, cozy yet spacious enough that you're not hitting other people with your elbows. Food was tasty & fresh, although the servings are on the petite side, since customers are supposed to order a bunch and then share. Churros for dessert were so yummy, warm, and light.The only thing I don't like is more a reflection on the owner than the restaurant: gratuity is included, but servers (or any of the other employees) don't see a dime of it. I know this for a fact. Somehow, that does not sit well with me.

p0qFSgDCPNXZbTVjzZ5XDQ.text: Delicious food! Quick Service! What more do you need?Highlights: - The food - that I had - was very good! I had the fish tacos and chicken quesadilla.- The portions were perfect. I'd say you'd be good with just one order of the tacos.- Located in a nice area of Notting Hill. I felt so hip eating there listening to everyone's conversations from law to painting!Lowlights: - The service was not especially friendly. But it was quick and effective and in no way unfriendly. - Limeade that I had was way too sugary.Overall: Great place for a quick meal! I have lived in places with some amazing Mexican food and this place - especially in London - beats most of them!

2U-S4qvW89tnC9egzOMdMg.text: Fantastic service, tacos and that hibiscus margarita. Very fresh flavors and a unique taste. Mmmmm. Lovely

YB2VWkFxRmdCgGzeCMn64w.text: This is a solid spin on Mexican cuisine with bold flavours and big portions. My kind of happy meal.Kicking things off with a Bloody Maria, it was all kinds of fun and spice done right. My companion had the original Michelada which was way too spicy for both of us, every sip like a smack in the face.Thankfully the food was much kinder. A fried oyster that took several bites with a yummy sauce went down easy. The cheesy grilled corn was a delight.Then came the giant tacos. These are no tiny Mexican street tacos, they are super sized. For the price they needed to be but worth every pence! The pork belly was thick cut and tender, great bbq sauce and crunchy sweet potato topping. The fish tacos took it to a new level. Creamy sauce atop perfectly cooked fish with cabbage. I highly recommend it!Overall service was quick and friendly. Busy but fun ambiance. I would gladly return for more delicious bites.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Bloody Maria and Michelada - super spicy!
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Fried oyster and corn
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly and fish tacos

doe5oYd1QR2dZjY8vDp10Q.text: Awful service. Hostess lies to you. Don't go. She strings you along for a long time and then claims to forget you're on the list. Awful

GfhYLlGpX9JxgWRdzkS-fg.text: Ordered delivery via deliveroo at almost 11pm (after a major snafu in dinner plans). the food was at home in under 25 minutes. Extra half star just for that.Ordered some tacos which were lovely. Chorizo is amazing. Quesadillas weren't as crisp as I'd like them, so they had become a bit chewy. I expect they would taste better on location.Great nachos too. Meal came quickly, was tasty and filling. What's not to like?

1_JddlD4WqqC1wX5WhRmqQ.text: All I can say is yummmmm. Food and drink are absolutely delicious. I had the prawn tacos and my wife had the soft shell crab tacos.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

7J3gSRaEIttLQ8XT-vZ1Lg.text: Coming from California, I was skeptical... Mexican food outside of Mexico or Cali is always disappointing.  I have to admit, these tacos were tasty and margaritas were decent. The chips seemed house-made, and the tacos were flavorful.  My nitpick is that the flour tortilla was heated to the point of being stiff - it should still be soft - but otherwise my stomach was super-happy. I'm glad to know there's a decent taco option in London!

V8wUt71y3Pu_FHOSXMAdAQ.text: Having come in from taco capital of the world (LA) outside of Mexico, I'd have to say this experience was impressive. Was not expecting to find great tacos in the middle of Knoting Hill so bravo y espero que siguen teniendo mucho exito! I highly recommend the tacos de carnitas and tacos de barbacoa. It's always best to pair it with your favorite tequila to finish off the experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

xGUYpXnvoTERljaPjgfZLA.text: We had a great dinner at Taqueria- so fresh and so delicious. Our tacos were like art- the flavor combinations were just right and presentation was great. And the grapefruit margaritas were amazing!

IBcuYpd-5GDpMY-JmqFHYQ.text: If you're looking for London's best tacos, then stop looking. There're at Taquerie, just off Westbourne Grove in the heart of Notting Hill. And there might be a few nice lil' tequila cocktails on the menu as well... #justsaying cakeandwhisky.com/2016/0…

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Fish tacos at Taqueria, Westbourne Grove
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Cocktails at Taqueria, Westbourne Grove
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Roadside chicken tacos at Taqueria, Westbourne Grove

DkFSt9cA0L7nh42JFCwSUw.text: It's taken me a while to get over the transition from African to Mexican.  It's been a few years now and I can't remember the former's name ...  but the African kitchen that used to occupy this spot for ages and ages used to be quirky, delicious and always packed.Taqueria has a much more orderly feel to it now, I doubt if the ambience is authentically Mexican.  The dishes are.  It's part of the new wave of Mexican tapas-style places (an upmarket Wahaca) which replaced the super-sized Tex-Mex outlets of yesteryear.On our last visit the dark part of the restaurant (three tables on the side with the toilets and till) was completely empty, but we were still asked whether we had a booking before being shown to our table.  On the whole, it was the service that let the place down ...  it's actually really hard to write a negative review when the guy who serves you is so lovely and friendly.  But he just wasn't a trained waiter - more likely the friend (lover?) of one of the other staff who stepped in on a quiet day.  We really should have refused to pay the compulsory service charge but my friend was too embarrassed.So, what happened?  We had a couple of kids in tow who don't like their food spicy.  It seemed no problem to order mild versions of some of the dishes - just for them to arrive smothered in chilli sauce.  The next round was perfect.  The third was sprinkled with raw chillies, so strong they burnt your tongue - and left a trace on the dish.  Have you ever tried to enjoy dinner with fussy teenagers?!  The quacamole and chips we had hoped to nibble on while we were waiting arrived only after we asked for it twice more and after we almost finished everything else.  We were asked if we wanted desert while some of us were still eating our mains ...  actually, there is not such thing as main course here, but they made a point of serving each dish separately contradicting the idea of sharing and tasting.Overall, a real let down.  We went home feeling flat - and still a bit hungry.  A proper waiter would have had an easy job upselling ....

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom

mleHFn0XQqk4gTGvRSln6w.text: Just home from this place.The good:- the carnitas tacos. they were really delicious. some of the best I've had in Europe (which isn't a high bar, but still...)The bad:- portion sizes. I agree with the chica who said "tacos come with two tortillas and give me three, not two"- the chips - they were staleThe ugly - the bartender. We had our meal at the bar because the tables were full. The guy was way more concerned with trying to seduce female waitstaff than with helping customers.  We ordered wine, which apparently was our first mistake. This guy clearly love to do his little shaker dance when making cocktails, and we outrageously deprived him of that opportunity. He also gave my boyfriend a totally machismo and condescending look as if to say, "real men don't order wine." Then he proceeded to bring me the wrong wine (red instead of white) and when I pointed it out, he blamed me for saying it wrong, when in fact I had read it directly from the menu. (And as you can see from the volume of (mostly positive) yelp reviews I've done, it wasn't my first wine ordering rodeo. When I pointed on the menu to the wine I had correctly ordered, and highlighted the fact that it was in the "white wine column" he said nothing and disdainfully replaced the wine, and any chance we had at having a positive experience was over. He then ignored us until our dinner was over (someone else brought the tacos). When I noticed that there was a discretionary service charge included in the bill, I asked to have it removed. This is something I never do. As a generously tipping Californian, I always leave at least 15%, even for bad service. Something about this guy just really got under my skin, so I asked to have the discretionary tip removed. I paid the bill in cash and asked for change back, he proceeded to give me 8 dollars change, in change, after slamming some things around and taking his sweet time and claiming they only had tens. He really ruined the dinner for us.No bueno!

Q6FLM49Q6vsyijP2Pc3tcA.text: Food:  Tapas style but just ok, not good enough size or quality for the price tags.  Fish tacos were the best.  Drinks:  HUGE mezcal and tequila menu.  This was the highlight for me.  Great cocktails.Ambience:  Lacking.  The music could barely be heard and the lights were on so bright.  Needed more atmosphere for the type of service, food and drinks on offer.Overall i wouldn't rush to go back for an expensive average meal.

WPML6P8TSVZYt9876MV3hQ.text: Great variety of tapas-style tacos with vibrant flavours on a cosy corner of Westbourne Grove.  The plantain tacos and the Carnitas were the winners by group vote and the guac was good starter.  Corn tortillas gave it a seemingly (not any sort of Mexican food connoisseur!) authentic touch over big chain restaurant Mexican food.  The Chorizo quesadilla was a bit disappointing, but the variety of margaritas (hibiscus and grapefruit were tasted and approved!) was a plus.Restaurant is on the small side, so make reservations if possible, or be prepared for a wait.

sZkXG-TIqGNEtfSCH_0sMg.text: One of my dearest friends is totally mucho loco for all things Mexican and she wanted to try out Taquería. I love Mexican food so I didn't have to think twice. First thing you notice when you walk in is the very grilly grill smell. And just so you know that smell will follow you home as well. Other than that all good by the look of the place and the waiters welcomed us politely and with a smile. All the waitors also spoke both english and spanish which was very cool in my opinion. I ordered 2 scallops, a ceviche and a fish taco. They were actually all very tasty and I got my tummy full but I wasn't very hungry to start with. So the portions were quite small especially for the prices. The two scallops set me back like 3,5 pounds, the ceviche was 7,5 and the fish taco was like 6. So a little bit pricy if you want to eat a lot. Also I couldn't resist the churros for dessert as the lovely waitress gave them such high praise and she was totally right - they were divine. For a drink I had a nice Mexican bottled beer (which was brought in a chilled glass and was heavenly). So if you don't mind smelling like a grill and overpaying a little bit for your meal then I recommend Taquería, because it was definitely delicious and a nice visit overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Churros
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Fish tacos
Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Ceviche

6E8l-IquUb1NQes2gsMDXg.text: We live so close to this taqueria but never dropped by for some reason until this afternoon. Didn't make a reservation (for lunch?!) so got seated at the bar which was fine with us. I got a jalapeño taco, and a chipotle salsa quesadilla with a guava agua Fresca. My boyfriend got the same quesadilla and a potato and mushroom taco with beer. The food was absolutely delicious and at first the quantity seemed small but actually I'm quite full because there is a lot of waiting involved. I would definitely come back here for the tacos (and also cuz their alcoholic drinks sound delicious!! Though the agua fresca was also amazing and a perfect hangover cure :p)

photos.caption: Photo of Taqueria - London, United Kingdom. Guava agua Fresca, jalapeno tacos and mushroom potato tacos

LNXLYF1a_HBBDMKQAIojLw.text: This is by far my favourite Mexican place in all of London. I am originally from California and my parents live in Arizona which both border Mexico so I know a little about proper Mexican food. Sorry to say but most "Mexican" places in London just don't cut it.Here they serve authentic tacos and other fabulous creations. I always order the carne asada tacos, the marinated pork tacos with pineapple, and the classic margaritas. The meat is always fresh and they use proper corn tortillas. The plantains are also fantastic and are served slightly squishy not fried hard which personally I prefer. Whenever I leave here I am happily stuffed and satisfied.All the drinks here are very good. They are strong and not overly sweet with syrups and other artificial sweetners. Just good old fashioned mixed drinks. They also have a decent beer selection.The prices are very decent for what you get and especially for this part of town. It's usually pretty busy but even without a reservation I have never waited too long to be seated and served. The ambiance isn't exactly date night worthy, you won't find table cloths and dimmed lighting here. But you will find amazing food that gets everyone talking. Its great for groups since the portions are small everyone can get something different and try everything together.I should also mention they sell tortillas, spices and cheese!!!

T9GcNnGauHMxHuwC8g1T7A.text: Love love love tacos. Sad sad sad that London doesn't have that many taquerias. We came here for a group dinner and I loved the large selection of different tacos available. None of them were mind blowing in their filling selection but still better than a Wahaca or some other chain. We ordered up a starter of guac and chips and ceviche. The ceviche was small as London usually serves it but very fresh, sharp and delicious. We ordered a fish tacos and a pork carnitas as well. The fish tacos were fantastically moreish, with the right amount of crispyness and saucy. My favourite. The pork was a bit uninspired for me and not very visually appealing either, so I let my boyfriend finish the whole plate. We had a great meal here. It's not cheap as each tacos plate is about £7-8 so you will end up spending. Pretty ironic as Mexican should be a cheap food. I'd definitely go back if I was in the area.

eDoib2Qql-Wzyt3uznAZFQ.text: I'm Mexican & Was Really Craving Some Tacos So I Came Here. First Of All, Traditional Tacos At A "Taqueria" Come With Two Tortillas With Each Taco, Not One, Stop Being Greedy With Those Tortillas. I Asked For More Tortillas To Layer My Tacos And I Was Charged For The Tortillas. Wow. Also, The Price For ONLY 2 Tacos, With Only Two Tortillas, Ridiculous!! How About You Add A Third Taco For That Price & Put Two Tortillas For Each Taco? I Don't Get Full Off Only Two Tacos. Call Me A Fatty, But That's Just Me. I Love Tacos! But, I Guess Only In Mexico & USA You'll Get Two Tortillas Per Taco & Numerous Tacos For A Decent Price. Something Positive, The Food Was Decent. Birria & Carnitas Were Good

87Q10KiWjtUc99UfcZHL-A.text: Best Mexican food in the notting hill area. I have gone multiple times and the food and drinks have never disappointed. The service is fast and friendly. You most likely will need a reservation unless you don't mind sitting at the bar.

BgoDIl3tQtGZcAQE-BJGig.text: I got the plantain tacos and OMG delicious. And I am picky as hell on Mexican food, having lived on the Tex-Mex border for two years. Proper corn tortillas. The caramelized plantains were loaded with rich crema- a perfect combo of slightly sweet and savoury. This definitely hit my cravings! I was also glad the servers spoke Spanish =)

bHdUBF8yG7jkIqnrCAzFIQ.text: I like this place. The food is good and it has an authentic feel. Yet it's a bit pricey for the portions you get. The servings are mostly tacos, but hey, it's a Taqueria. If you're lucky enough to be in Notting Hill and need a fix, then definitely give this place a go. Try to not go there on a completely empty stomach if you are on a budget. Your stomach will be happy but your wallet will not.

I8leBS_hPC3IYBPXXgM9NQ.text: I am in two minds about this place. I have probably been around 5 times, so it can't be that bad. The food can be nice, it can be really good, on a bad day - it can be too greasy. Simple, Mexican rather than American Tex Mex. The drinks seem to be where they make their margins so order with care. Its something about the location, decoration and nice waiters that have me returning there. I like the carnitas, the avocado with sweet onion salt and coriander, the black beans with cheese. On a sour note, last time I went there for lunch on the weekend, they had employed a new manager, a pint sized young woman, who strutted around with a clip-board the whole time and did nothing to alleviate the busy waiters (because, you know, she is the manager...!) She kept dissuading people from staying by saying they would have to wait over an hour. It turned out to be more like 20 minutes! Why are they paying this little person a salary exactly?

zWUvtTvQAr7PH9VLcYa8Hg.text: For those that know the American Southwest, this place is like a Taco Truck that runs over a semi-fine dining restaurant.  It doesn't seem to quit hit it out of the park, another Americanism, but it is pretty darn good.  The fresh take on classic dirty borderland taco truck tacos is fun and interesting. The flavors are traditional and the selections are standard of Taquerias.  However, the part that confused me, because I was not standing on the side of a highway dodging oncoming traffic, was that the the portions were just as small as you would get for a roadside snack, not a sit down restaurant.  A taco is just a taco at this place.  If you are expecting a hearty helping of rice and beans, forget it.  However, the food was really great and super fresh.  A nice helping of southwestern spiciness too.  Not bad for being thousands of miles from the home of Taco Trucks and Taquerias.

YnbcpjGOyuxTFzj_03ljPQ.text: Having grown up in LA sampling some of the best tacos I can honestly say that this place serves up great food! This place makes real tacos! The carntias and cochinita pibil are the real thing. I have tried several of the tacos and the beans and have not been dissapointed. The only reason I have not given it 5 stars is that for serving what is typically mexican street food this place can be a bit expensive. But given the lack of good mexican around it definitely is one my favorites. Shame they don't offer tapatio but their own salsas are wonderful.

d90vZ0q65t-5fXdpOnoeog.text: Taqueria is not glitzy or glamorous. It is a pretty no fuss Mexican but gains serious credibility points from fans of Mexican food for the products used.
